comments.author: Jenny
comments.content: This looks just wonderful!  Glad you were able to make good use of that dough after all.

comments.author: Marina@Picnic at Marina
comments.content:
:) Lovely piroshki!  I know that bakery on Pike Place Market, it's a good one. There is another place in Auburn, that makes fantastic piroshki, both baked and deep fried. They also have a great selection of other baked goods and variety of vegetarian meals. Love that place! 
Traditionally, piroshki were made of rye flour, and only recently wheat flour started to dominate.  So you made an authentic piroshki! :) All is missing is a drink, that piroshki were served with: kvas, which is fermented drink made off stale rye bread, water and a little sugar. You can see a photo of kvas (http://www.picnicatmarina.com/2012/06/cold-summer-soup-okroshka.html). :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Oh my god, the kvas looks fantastic! Interesting that piroshki were traditionally made with rye - I had done some basic searching and hadn't come up with that, though I'm not surprised given where they are from. If you know where to find a traditional recipe, please share.

comments.author: angela@spinachtiger
comments.content: Looks beautiful. I love to see old world recipes continue and dance with some new twists.

comments.author: Irina
comments.content:
Hi Michael! 

I am teaching a hands-on piroshky class at PCC Cooks this fall and would love to share my recipes with you! We'll be making savory piroshky with cabbage and carrots and sweet ones with apples, as well as larger, sharing-size pies with mushrooms and onions. I use wheat flour, so my recipe is not "traditional" in that sense, but it does come from my mother-in-law who lives in Siberia! 

Here is a link to the class schedule: http://www.pccnaturalmarkets.com/pcccooks/classes/detail.php?id=1691. I hope you can join us! 

Irina

comments.author: Marina@Picnic at Marina
comments.content: I'll have to translate for you some information then... :) I hit some technical problems with my computer today. I have a few books on history of Russian food downloaded to my computer, and wasn't able to un-zip it. Let me deal with it, and then I'll send you the information. Are you like me interested in food anthropology?! :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I certainly find food history and anthropology interesting, but please don't go to too much trouble! That sounds like it could be a lot of work.

comments.author: whaleshark
comments.content: This looks fantastic! I would like to try and taste this. This is a challenging recipe for me because it's my first time but I would do anything just to make this recipe perfect.

comments.author: Amy of Vspot
comments.content: Yum! I love everything about this, great job.

comments.author: jenbeans
comments.content: Definitely a recipe I will try - already bookmarked! Thanks for the idea!

comments.author: swati
comments.content: wow ! great recipe, well worth the work, can't wait to try it out....

comments.author: Sara @ The Cozy Herbivore
comments.content: Oh my, these look heavenly. I must admit that I instantly clicked on the picture because they looked a big like stuffed soft pretzels, which I am totally addicted to, but I LOVE the idea of a ry flour calzone-like dish. I can't wait to give these a try!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Well I think the idea of doing them in a pretzel crust is outstanding!

comments.author: Vegan
comments.content: The piroshki is mouthwatering and I can't wait to make it on my kitchen. What other types of cheese can I use for this recipe?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: You could use any kind of cheese that will melt - so, not Parmesan for example.
